title: Migrate Oomph's setup URIs to use the new GitHub locations
body: We also need the setup archiver to create a setups.zip that can be consumed by older installers and installations that are using the legacy locations.

title: NA
body:
I have a feeling this is caused by changes in p2 core's Activator that required changes here:

https://github.com/eclipse-oomph/oomph/blame/83e93b0dfd53cff61eb77694df731edfa10314b7/plugins/org.eclipse.oomph.p2.core/src/org/eclipse/oomph/p2/internal/core/ProvisioningAgentProvider.java#L42

Can you try it with a "nightly" installer?

https://download.eclipse.org/justj/?file=oomph/products/latest

I should probably change the configuration to specify using Oomph's nightly builds explicitly if that works...

title: NA
body: i will try

title: NA
body: Did work with nightly.

title: NA
body:
So it's as I suspected. Safest for the future will be to explicitly specify Oomph's nightly build repo since we know we are installing an SDK I-Build that make have things that break and older Oomph.  Hopefully not too often.  😢 

I'll try to get to this sooner rather than later.  Still migrating Oomph right now...

title: NA
body:
Given this problem affects **everyone** installing an an I-build version of the  Eclipse SDK, I fixed this in the catalog and in catalog generator.  Cool that the Oomph commit is cross linked back to this issue. 🆒 

Thanks for reporting the issue and for testing the nightly build installer!  😁

title: NA
body: This is quite an old installer and you are trying to install quite an old version of jee. Is there a reason not to use the latest installer to install the latest version on jee?  Note that the latest installer can be used to install older products if you switch to advanced mode via the menu. I can only fix problems that are reproduced with the latest version.

title: NA
body: Given no answers to questions, I'll assume the latest installer works.

title: "Trust Artifacts" dialog not modal
body:
it can hide behind the Eclipse Installer Window, which look and feels like program is stuck:
![image](https://github.com/eclipse-oomph/oomph/assets/51790620/ea7c1ea3-fee2-4928-9cc0-243dc31e7fc9)

title: NA
body:
Yes, I've had that happen too, though in the Progress dialog in the IDE.  In any case, this would need to change in p2:

- https://github.com/eclipse-equinox/p2/blob/02f345d92a157d6bb14badae11f866daac01d11a/bundles/org.eclipse.equinox.p2.ui/src/org/eclipse/equinox/internal/p2/ui/dialogs/TrustCertificateDialog.java#L85
- https://github.com/eclipse-equinox/p2/blob/02f345d92a157d6bb14badae11f866daac01d11a/bundles/org.eclipse.equinox.p2.ui/src/org/eclipse/equinox/internal/p2/ui/dialogs/TrustAuthorityDialog.java#L86

title: NA
body: While I would like to make the dialog modal, doing so would affect not just the installer's use of it.  There is always a risk that a dialog such as this one that opens at some arbitrary time driven by a background job might appear while some other modal dialog/interaction is in progress.   Maybe I can do something that affects only the installer, e.g., looking for dialog shells when the installer shell is activated...

title: NA
body: I have a feeling that these dialogs could use SWT.ON_TOP rather than making them modal...

title: NA
body: After running into this twice this week, I decided to take action.  😱

title: Variables are shown in random order
body:
every once i start Oomph the Variables are shown in a different order.
Example1:
![image](https://github.com/eclipse-oomph/oomph/assets/51790620/71ba7bfd-45f8-4308-a9ab-fb096127a5c8)
Example2:
![image](https://github.com/eclipse-oomph/oomph/assets/51790620/6b91290c-1b9b-4423-b101-0faa76c354c3)

Can even be triggered by using  "back" and "next" buttons.
That's irritating.

title: NA
body:
The only way I've been able to get the second order is to check and uncheck "Show all variables".  

It looks to me like the logic for the order is deterministic.  There is some reordering involved though to keep "related" variables closer together and to keep impactful variables near the beginning.  You're really sure this really comes up randomly differently initially or that it randomly changes for next/back navigation?    I really cannot reproduce that, and not for lack of trying...

Note too that I assume you get to this with the platform configuration, but after a dozen clicks on that all with the same "picture number one", I'm not convinced there is any randomness.  Please double check your steps to reproduce the issue.

title: NA
body:
I have seen the  different orders multiple times in the last year. I reported this when i was able to reproduce it by back/next. Typically i go back+back, uncheck Bundle pool, and go next+next.
Today i could not reproduce it with back/next either. Seems to be only sometimes random

title: NA
body: I can't remember having seen them switch between a Back > Next page switch. But I can confirm the order changing between restarts and selecting them same product and projects.

title: NA
body: If I cannot reproduce it then I cannot fix it.

title: NA
body:
The order of variables in the dialog seems to depend on the order of their usage in the setup.
That's why we try to get a defined order by introducing an internal variable referencing all user variables in the desired order and put this one first in the setup.
But even with this approach, the variables that are used in filters (bold label) are automatically placed. The same for variables inside conditional containers.

title: NA
body:
Yes, the ones used in filters are intentionally moved to the front because they affect which tasks are collected and that in turn can affect which other variables are used and hence prompted/displayed...

If someone can provide something  or some steps where the order changes or appears different "each time" I can investigate.  But if I can't reproduce anything like it, I'm at a loss to make progress on it.  Sorry.  😱

title: NA
body:
It's complain about this file not existing:
```
C:\Users\User\.p2\pool\plugins\org.eclipse.equinox.simpleconfigurator_1.4.200.v20221111-1340.jar 
```
I assume that file really does not exist, correct?

Unfortunately Windows anti-virus can block files being moved/renamed leading to problems like this one.  If a second attempt to installs fails in this same way, then you need to try to repair the bundle pool to fix this missing/broken artifact as described here:

https://www.eclipse.org/setups/installer/question/

Specifically the latest sentence here is relevant:

> Use the eclipse installer's Bundle Pools... menu item to manage where this pool is physically located on disk; this location can become large. The Bundle Pool Management dialog supports garbage collecting of unused artifacts, i.e., if you delete an installation, the artifacts it uses can potentially be removed from disk. In addition, if some artifact becomes corrupted, or if a corrupted artifact is downloaded from some mirror site, this dialog can be used to detect the damage and to repair it. 

Please let me know how that works out!

title: Oomph since 1.29.0 forces https even for http repos
body:
So I've started to get familiar with the Oomph setup ecosystem, and figured to need some web server to provide one or another artifact.
For simplicity to find the way through, I'm using some local web server where I can either disable SSL, or have some self-signed certificate at hand only. The idea here is to learn what it needs before I ask our infra to provide a proper SSL enabled web server.

While making good progress with http repositories using Oomph up to version 1.28.0, Oomph version since 1.29.0 silently switches to https, and fails because of missing proper SSL setup in that local web server:

- Disabling SSL leads to 'Connection refused' at https port 443,
- Enabling SSL using self-signed certificate leads to 'unable to find valid certification path to requested target', because I don't use some public certification authority.

While I understand the motivation behind forcing https everywhere, either I need some option to disable that silent change to https, or I need some option to accept my self-signed certificate.

Thoughts?

title: NA
body:
This is done by p2 for your safety and comfort:

https://eclipse.dev/eclipse/news/4.28/platform.php#force-https

You can change that via the preferences.

title: Dialog for permanent location not shown on Windows for long user names
body:
On Windows, the Dialog asking to store the Installer to a permanent location is not showing, if the temp directory contains a shortended Windows 8.3 file path, e.g. `java.io.tmpdir=C\:\\Users\\LONGUS~1\\AppData\\Local\\Temp\\`.
This happens for each username longer than 8 characters by default.

Reason is the following comparison between a canonicalized path and one that is taken directly from a system property:
![Screenshot 2023-10-06 140905](https://github.com/eclipse-oomph/oomph/assets/117865836/1e63fc80-7c1f-4ead-aa2f-d061c9829ce5)
(`OS.getCurrentLauncher()` does `IOUtil.getCanonicalFile(launcherFile)`, but `PropertiesUtil.getTmpDir()` doesn't)

title: NA
body:
Thank you for the details!   🏅 

The next build will have the fix.

title: Support shared/read only install of a product
body:
When I launch the installer I'm currently presented with this standard options:

![grafik](https://github.com/eclipse-oomph/oomph/assets/1331477/f4aaeac1-97f5-43d6-ae83-5010e8bf2b3b)

as part of the [Eclipse WG imitative to supporting secured installation layouts for eclipse](https://gitlab.eclipse.org/eclipse-wg/ide-wg/ide-wg-dev-funded-efforts/ide-wg-dev-funded-program-planning-council-top-issues/-/issues/18), it was decided that the most safe way seems to install eclipse in a read-only way so probably only elevated administration user can modify the original install of eclipse (especially placing new file in the root of eclipse what might be a source of [DLL Injection](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/DLL_injection) or replacing the `eclipse.exe`  and similar treats.

Oompf should therefore help the user to make things more secured by the following ways

1. If installed a product it should make sure that the folder and its files are only writable by that user for example using [NIO Path API](https://docs.oracle.com/javase/8/docs/api/java/nio/file/Files.html#setPosixFilePermissions-java.nio.file.Path-java.util.Set-) if that is not possible we might want to warn the user about this insecurity
2. There might be an option to make the install even **readonly** for this purpose the product has to be started once with `-initialize` and then can be made readonly as described [here](https://help.eclipse.org/latest/topic/org.eclipse.platform.doc.isv/reference/misc/multi_user_installs.html?cp=2_1_6_7). Even though eclipse chooses a default of `<user-home-dir>/.eclipse/<product-id>_<product-version>/configuration` for the private user part, this might be configurable as well for the convenience of the user.
3. There might even be an option to create a **shared install** the main difference is that the product will not installed with user-right but _elevated rights_ that make the install read only and even not modifiable by the current user account. This is the most complex because it will require integration with the native operation system way of requesting elevated permissions but thanks to [FFM API](https://openjdk.org/jeps/442) even that would be solvable from java

Option 1+2 seem quite straight forward, but still have one flaw: If my user account get compromised even for a short time (e.g. forget to logout while taking a coffee) my eclipse might get compromised even though of course this opens up for much more serve security problems. Option 3 is the most complex but what one today might expect from modern installers, especially in managed environments.

I have used shared-installs (manually configured of course) in the past for supporting Windows-Terminal Server, so even beside the security aspect supporting shared-installs would be great for the users (or more their admins).

title: NA
body:
Some of concerns are covered by documentation here:

https://www.eclipse.org/setups/installer/question/

E.g., one can avoid using a bundle pool or one can create shared installations even with a bundle pool running as an admin and managing the location of the bundle pool.

title: Key bindings
body:
I'm trying to configure key bindings using Oomph but I'm failing. 

I start from a pristine, completely default set of key bindings and I'm trying to bind the `Format` command (currently bound to `Shift+Ctrl+F`) to `Shift+Ctrl+Alt+F12`.
![image](https://github.com/eclipse-oomph/oomph/assets/813926/1f45a1a1-01b8-45ce-a059-43f659cce8cc)
I press the Oomph recorder button and I perform the change.
![image](https://github.com/eclipse-oomph/oomph/assets/813926/8b811c00-5c9b-4294-bb07-641e0dc0b31e)
And then do `Apply and close`.  
The `org.eclipse.ui.commands` entry is updated in my setup file.
![image](https://github.com/eclipse-oomph/oomph/assets/813926/df8af28e-a46e-40e4-8eea-65c69a7f498d)
This is the XML of the change:
```
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<org.eclipse.ui.commands>
<keyBinding contextId="org.eclipse.ui.textEditorScope" keyConfigurationId="org.eclipse.ui.defaultAcceleratorConfiguration" keySequence="CTRL+SHIFT+F"/>
<keyBinding commandId="org.eclipse.lsp4e.format" contextId="org.eclipse.ui.textEditorScope" keyConfigurationId="org.eclipse.ui.defaultAcceleratorConfiguration" keySequence="ALT+CTRL+SHIFT+F12"/>
</org.eclipse.ui.commands>
```

I'm surprised that there is an entry:
```
<keyBinding contextId="org.eclipse.ui.textEditorScope" keyConfigurationId="org.eclipse.ui.defaultAcceleratorConfiguration" keySequence="CTRL+SHIFT+F"/>
```

IIUIC correctly, then this entry is responsible for unbinding the pre-existing key binding.  The surprising part is that it does not mention _which_ binding exactly to remove.  For example, it is possible that multiple bindings for this key-combination exists in the same scope.  

OK, nevermind, let's continue and try to use this recorded change. 

I revert the updated key bindings by pushing `Restore Defaults` in the `Keys` tab of the  `Preference` window.  

Now, I try to re-apply my recorded key bindings.  I do `Perform setup tasks`.
![image](https://github.com/eclipse-oomph/oomph/assets/813926/c69c5c16-b0f9-404f-a6de-54ac0bb59b5e)

The resulting key bindings are unexpected:
![image](https://github.com/eclipse-oomph/oomph/assets/813926/cfd01e81-767f-4cd9-8ecc-8743f133dfde)

There is no key binding for `Format`.  What is more, there is no key binding either for `Go to Symbol in File`, `Go to Symbol in Work` ...  They seem to have disappeared.  Note that not all key bindings have disappeared.  Most remain.

I'm using Eclipse 2023-03
![image](https://github.com/eclipse-oomph/oomph/assets/813926/fc0571a5-5a67-44f3-bb54-2dd2565f7a01)

title: NA
body:
Yes, sorry, that doesn't work.  The representation is too complex/unusual to manage that way.  This is why there is specifically a Key Binding task

![image](https://github.com/eclipse-oomph/oomph/assets/208716/1ac4287d-b517-4f61-a384-9ba6c90bd916)

I've found them difficult to author though it does work...

title: NA
body:
I see.

I've added a `Key Binding Task` like so:

![image](https://github.com/eclipse-oomph/oomph/assets/813926/0e90285d-3a3e-4771-b9d3-3928719b774e)

which corresponds to this XML entry in my setup file:

```
<setupTask
        xsi:type="setup:CompoundTask"
        name="org.eclipse.ui.workbench">
      <setupTask
          xsi:type="workbench:KeyBindingTask"
          keys="ALT+CTRL+SHIFT+F10"
          command="org.eclipse.egit.ui.AbortRebase">
        <context
            id="org.eclipse.jdt.ui.javaEditorScope"/>
      </setupTask>
    </setupTask>
```

When I run my setup tasks, it doesn't seem to bind the key.  Am I missing something obvious?

title: NA
body:
When I try to perform that task, the preferences show that it appears to be bound as expected:

![image](https://github.com/eclipse-oomph/oomph/assets/208716/8e8ae5b0-1d30-4cf1-b0ad-b50f8e1895c0)

title: NA
body:
Got it to work.

For future reference, I learned stuff:

* One doesn't seem able to remove a key binding using a "key binding" task.  You can only add bindings.
* The underlying Eclipse key binding API seems flawed. `org.eclipse.jface.bindings.Binding` explains that you remove a key binding by registering a new binding that omits a command.  The problem is that this interface does not allow you to specifically say which binding needs to be removed: there could be multiple key bindings in the same scheme/context for the same key. It seems this interface will just randomly unbind one of possibly many bindings because the interface doesn't know which command is supposed to be unbound from the key.  That API also explains why the recorder sometimes registers multiple `keyBinding contextId="..." keyConfigurationId="..." keySequence="..."` operations.  I guess that the Preference dialog is just iterating through all the bindings of a key until it finally deletes the specific one you are trying to unbind.

title: For the target definition generator, support specifying which installable units should specify a version in the generated target
body:
As described here:

https://wiki.eclipse.org/Eclipse_Oomph_Authoring#Generating_PDE_Target_Definition_files_.28.2A.target.29_and_their_use_by_Tycho

One can generate versions but it's an all or nothing effect:

> generateVersions : Boolean := whether to also generate the IU versions in the .target file. It can fix some issues where IUs require a version that is not the most recent version available in the repositories.

Provide support for specifying a pattern so that one can generate versions for a subset of the IUs.

title: NA
body: The documentation is updated as well.

title: Ensure that agent *.info resources can be read in the future using the encoding currently being used
body:
Currently org.eclipse.oomph.p2.internal.core.PersistentMap is used to read and write *.info resources as used the agent manager infrastructure.  It effectively uses the default system encoding.  Unfortunately Java will soon change the default encoding to be UTF-8 and if any of these resources contain non-ASCII characters that will result in the resources not loading correct.

To prevent this, we can create an encoding.info resource that's stored using UTF-8 encoding to record the current encoding being used for all the other *.info resources.  This will ensure that we can continue to use the same encoding as is being used by older/current versions of Oomph while also ensuring that newer versions of Oomph with newer versions of Java will continue to use the correct/current encoding now and in the future.

title: Oomph fails due to recent XML parser vulnerability changes
body:
When trying to edit an Dynamic Working Set configuration via Preferences > Oomph > Working Sets > Edit, I see this error in _some_ of my IDEs, but not in all. The error message reminds me of the recent XML parser vulnerability changes from https://gitlab.eclipse.org/security/vulnerability-reports/-/issues/8 where one of the mitigations was to disallow unknown protocols, if I understood it right.

```
java.net.MalformedURLException: unknown protocol: index
	at java.base/java.net.URL.<init>(URL.java:779)
	at java.base/java.net.URL.<init>(URL.java:654)
	at java.base/java.net.URL.<init>(URL.java:590)
	at org.eclipse.emf.ecore.resource.impl.URIHandlerImpl.createInputStream(URIHandlerImpl.java:199)
	at org.eclipse.emf.ecore.resource.impl.ExtensibleURIConverterImpl.createInputStream(ExtensibleURIConverterImpl.java:358)
	at org.eclipse.emf.ecore.resource.impl.ResourceImpl.load(ResourceImpl.java:1314)
	at org.eclipse.emf.ecore.resource.impl.ResourceSetImpl.demandLoad(ResourceSetImpl.java:259)
	at org.eclipse.emf.ecore.resource.impl.ResourceSetImpl.demandLoadHelper(ResourceSetImpl.java:274)
	at org.eclipse.emf.ecore.resource.impl.ResourceSetImpl.getResource(ResourceSetImpl.java:406)
	at org.eclipse.emf.ecore.resource.impl.ResourceSetImpl.getEObject(ResourceSetImpl.java:220)
	at org.eclipse.emf.ecore.util.EcoreUtil.resolve(EcoreUtil.java:209)
	at org.eclipse.emf.ecore.util.EcoreUtil.resolve(EcoreUtil.java:269)
	at org.eclipse.emf.ecore.impl.BasicEObjectImpl.eResolveProxy(BasicEObjectImpl.java:1516)
	at org.eclipse.emf.ecore.util.EcoreEList.resolveProxy(EcoreEList.java:206)
	at org.eclipse.emf.ecore.util.EcoreEList.resolve(EcoreEList.java:161)
	at org.eclipse.emf.ecore.util.EObjectResolvingEList.resolve(EObjectResolvingEList.java:60)
	at org.eclipse.emf.common.util.BasicEList.get(BasicEList.java:348)
	at org.eclipse.emf.ecore.util.EContentsEList$FeatureIteratorImpl.hasNext(EContentsEList.java:514)
	at org.eclipse.emf.ecore.util.EContentsEList$FeatureIteratorImpl.next(EContentsEList.java:595)
	at org.eclipse.emf.edit.ui.provider.DiagnosticDecorator$LiveValidator$2.run(DiagnosticDecorator.java:521)
	at org.eclipse.core.internal.jobs.Worker.run(Worker.java:63)
```
Unfortunately I have not yet been able to reproduce this with a platform IDE or similar, but only with IDEs for a custom setup in our company. Therefore I'm not sure if the issue is valid, or if we have to eventually edit something in our company Oomph setup instead.

I guess the offending part in the setup file is the container here, which has been unchanged since years.
```
  <logicalProjectContainer
      xsi:type="setup:ProjectCatalog"
      href="index:/org.eclipse.setup#//@projectCatalogs[name='ETAS%20Projects']"/>
```

title: NA
body:
The `index:` only works when there are redirections.  The constant defined here:

https://github.com/eclipse-oomph/oomph/blob/c981e3ed3694841c61f4a1dccb496b0e5435ce3d/plugins/org.eclipse.oomph.setup.core/src/org/eclipse/oomph/setup/internal/core/SetupContext.java#L137

It is generally redirected to this by default:

https://github.com/eclipse-oomph/oomph/blob/c981e3ed3694841c61f4a1dccb496b0e5435ce3d/plugins/org.eclipse.oomph.setup.core/src/org/eclipse/oomph/setup/internal/core/SetupContext.java#L141

E.g., 

https://github.com/eclipse-oomph/oomph/blob/c981e3ed3694841c61f4a1dccb496b0e5435ce3d/plugins/org.eclipse.oomph.setup.core/src/org/eclipse/oomph/setup/internal/core/SetupContext.java#L141

So if you're seeing such an exception, then some appropriate redirection has not kicked it for the resource set in which the load is happening...

title: NA
body: Thanks Ed for that explanation. So we can definitely close the issue and I will investigate locally why the redirection doesn't kick in (I know where it's configured). Sorry for raising a false alert with the CVE.

title: NA
body: No problem.  Better to report a problem that turns out not to be a problem than to ignore what could be a serious problem!

title: TargetDefinitionGenerator does not put all the units in the target definition file
body:
Hi

I've just started experiment with the (cool) generator for the target platform definition file (https://wiki.eclipse.org/Eclipse_Oomph_Authoring#Generating_PDE_Target_Definition_files_.28.2A.target.29_and_their_use_by_Tycho).

I started to use that for EMF Parsley, the RAP version where defining a target definition file is a small nightmare (due to "slicer", required for RAP).

This is the content related in the setup file:

```xml
  <project name="rap"
      label="RAP">
    <setupTask
        xsi:type="setup.targlets:TargletTask">
      <targlet
          name="${scope.project.label}"
          activeRepositoryList="${eclipse.target.platform}"
          includeAllRequirements="false">
        <annotation
            source="http:/www.eclipse.org/oomph/targlets/TargetDefinitionGenerator">
          <detail
              key="location">
            <value>${git.clone.location}/devtools/org.eclipse.emf.parsley.targetplatform/simrel.rap.oomph.tp.target</value>
          </detail>
          <detail
              key="sortLocations">
            <value>false</value>
          </detail>
          <detail
              key="includeAllPlatforms">
            <value>false</value>
          </detail>
          <detail
              key="includeSource">
            <value>true</value>
          </detail>
          <detail
              key="singleLocation">
            <value>false</value>
          </detail>
          <detail
              key="extraUnits">
            <value>
              com.google.guava
              org.eclipse.emf.common
              org.eclipse.emf.edit
            </value>
          </detail>
        </annotation>
        <requirement
            name="org.eclipse.emf.parsley.rap.workspace.feature.group"/>
        <requirement
            name="org.eclipse.rap.feature.feature.group"/>
        <requirement
            name="org.eclipse.rap.sdk.feature.feature.group"/>
        <requirement
            name="org.eclipse.rap.examples.feature.feature.group"/>
        <requirement
            name="org.eclipse.rap.equinox.target.feature.feature.group"/>
        <requirement
            name="com.google.guava"/>
        <requirement
            name="org.eclipse.emf.common"/>
        <requirement
            name="org.eclipse.emf.ecore"/>
        <sourceLocator
            rootFolder="${git.clone.location}"
            locateNestedProjects="true"/>
...
```

And this is the generated target file:

```xml
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8" standalone="no"?>
<?pde version="3.8"?>
<target name="Generated from RAP" sequenceNumber="2">
  <locations>

    </location>
    <location includeAllPlatforms="false" includeConfigurePhase="true" includeMode="slicer" includeSource="true" type="InstallableUnit">
      <unit id="org.apache.commons.logging" version="0.0.0"/>
      <unit id="org.eclipse.emf.cdo.net4j" version="0.0.0"/>
      <unit id="org.eclipse.emf.cdo.server.db" version="0.0.0"/>
      <unit id="org.eclipse.emf.cdo.server.net4j" version="0.0.0"/>

```

As you see, no matter what I added as requirements `com.google.guava`,  `org.eclipse.emf.common` and `org.eclipse.emf.edit` (I tried also as `extraUnits`) these units are not part of the generated target definition file...

am I doing anything wrong?

By the way, those 3 bundles are required for one of the projects imported in the workspace, so Oomph correctly puts them in the modular target platform, but not in the generated target file...

thanks in advance

title: NA
body: Lots of options have defaults that you likely don't not want that way.  It would be awfully helpful if there were no TODOs in the documentation and it described the defaults.  I've not tried generated targets involving slicer.  In any case, case I expect you really want `generateImplicitUnits=true`, `minimizeImplicitUnits =false`, and `generateVersions=true`.  That will produce the most details, including with exact versions.  Later you might see if you need that much locked-in detail.

title: NA
body:
> Lots of options have defaults that you likely don't not want that way. It would be awfully helpful if there were no TODOs in the documentation and it described the defaults.

You mean in an ideal world! ;)

> I've not tried generated targets involving slicer. In any case, case I expect you really want `generateImplicitUnits=true`, `minimizeImplicitUnits =false`, and `generateVersions=true`. That will produce the most details, including with exact versions. Later you might see if you need that much locked-in detail.

Thank you @merks , these did the trick `generateImplicitUnits=true, minimizeImplicitUnits =false`

On a side note: I've just discovered that I can use a "planner" TP for RAP as well! In the past, I was including too many features in the TP (namely `org.eclipse.emf.cdo.feature.group` and `org.eclipse.net4j.feature.group`): these used to generate conflicts between RAP UI and RCP UI. But removing those features (not needed in the TP anyway), allows me to use "planner" and forget about the nightmares of "slider" :)

I guess we can close this issue.

title: Tycho pomless support?
body:
Oomph seems to not support importing tycho-pomless projects using the Maven Import task. During setup, the projects are able to be located in `MavenImportTask` (using `LocalProjectScanner` from m2e) but unable to be created because the `MavenProjectFactory` is only looking for files named `pom.xml` https://github.com/eclipse-oomph/oomph/blob/master/plugins/org.eclipse.oomph.resources/src/org/eclipse/oomph/resources/impl/MavenProjectFactoryImpl.java#L53. 

Do we have to use the `.project` files when importing tycho-pomless projects? It would be nice to not have to check these in.

title: NA
body: Does it work with m2e manually?  Is this something you could help improve/contribute assuming m2e can already do that?

title: NA
body:
m2e is able to import tycho-pomless projects fine. 

I did investigate how Oomph could support it but I think it would be a large change (although I'm not familiar at all with the codebase). It seems that the MavenProjectFactory (which extends XMLProjectFactory) only accepts a single file name, `pom.xml` in Maven's case. The issue is that Tycho generates many files that are equivalent to pom.xml, such as

pom.tycho
.polyglot.pom.tycho
.polyglot.META-INF
.polyglot.feature.xml

etc.

So either you have to create a factory for each of them, or modify the project factory system to allow a list of files to be given that are equivalent.

title: NA
body: Those other files are generated later in the build though aren't they, or do you check those in?

title: NA
NA
body:
I suspect that something in m2e is just creating projects based on the folder names or some such thing.  We could look for things like a MANIFEST.MF, a feature.xml, or a category.xml.  At least the first two have IDs, but a category.xml does not.  That's what makes me think it's maybe just using the folder name as a project name.   But I don't have a good sense of what it all imports and how it decides what to import and how to assign Eclipse project names to those things.

I need to investigate further, but I have so little time and so much else to do.  😱

body: Yes, this happens occasionally with no known way to reproduce the problem unfortunately.  I don't even have a good theory for how the artifact got into the pool while at the same time the p2 seems to think it needs to download the artifact because it's not yet in the pool.  Perhaps something put the artifact into the pool folder but failed to update the artifact metadata to reflect that fact.

title: NA
body:
related question: why is the pool used at all? I disabled it:
![image](https://github.com/eclipse-oomph/oomph/assets/51790620/6cf4afa9-43ae-4ed5-8afd-4419258e306e)

title: NA
body: There's always a pool, even if not a shared one.   That setting disables it for the p2 director task, i.e., so that the p2 direct creates an installation where its pool is colocated with (nested in) the installation.  This has no affect on targlets.

Does the file `C:\Users\SUBHA.p2\pool\plugins\org.eclipse.userstorage_1.2.0.v20210517-0327.jar` exist in the file system?  Probably not...  From past experience, sometimes virus checkers cause such problems by locking a file for scanning such that it cannot be moved to the correct final location...

You can try to repair the pool using this from the menu:

And Wait for the analysis to complete.  If there are damaged artifacts you can repair them:

title: Provider Eclipse Installer for Windows ARM64/Aarch64
body:
Currently the Eclipse Installer is just provided for Windows as X86_64 binary in https://www.eclipse.org/downloads/packages/. This affects also all prebuilt packages.
Please provide the Installer as native [ARM binary for Windows](https://developer.arm.com/solutions/os/windows-on-arm) as well. This will probably require a [JustJ release](https://eclipse.dev/justj/) for Windows ARM as well. Unfortunately neither https://jdk.java.net/21/ nor https://adoptium.net/temurin/releases/?os=windows (https://github.com/adoptium/adoptium-support/issues/616) provide distributions for that architecture on Windows (yet).

title: NA
body: This requires a bunch of things including justj which requires adoptium and the platform and epp without which the installer could not be built and would have nothing to install.  So don’t hold your breath . There is actually little point in having an open issue for this because if/when those other things happen, the installer will follow.

title: NA
body:
> There is actually little point in having an open issue for this

I disagree with that. An open issue allows to track the progress and get notified via subscription once that is done. Also it allows to track potential upstream dependencies. It doesn't really matter how long it takes, it is just a matter of transparency.

title: NA
body:
It’s not necessary for you to agree with me. 

In the interest of transparency, are you planning to do something somewhere or just asking and monitoring?

title: NA
body: I don't plan to work on this in the near future, as soon as I start I will for sure add a comment here.

title: NA
body:
@merks where is the installer code? I'll have a look to see if it can be compiled for Windows on Arm64.

Also, for the JustJ, I created some JustJ JREs in my [fork](https://github.com/chirontt/justj/releases), although I haven't done them recently. They were generated from the Microsoft JDKs for Windows on Arm64, but I don't know whether the resulting JREs can be used for Oomph (e.g. license, etc.) Do these JustJ JREs need be packaged in a p2 repo to be usable in a build?

title: NA
body:
Yes, they need to be in a p2 repository.   

https://download.eclipse.org/justj/jres/17/updates/

We  also do not have approval for JustJ grabbing the originating JDK from some arbitrary source.  So it's essential that Adoptium provide the JDKs on a regular basis in lock-step with the other JREs so we can add the URL to this structure:

https://github.com/eclipse-justj/justj/blob/80c7b947140922a9d6bd1ef034d6601e2540ba06/releng/org.eclipse.justj.releng/Jenkinsfile#L41-L66

I understand that the Adoptium effort is started...

title: NA
body:
> I understand that the Adoptium effort is started...

Great to hear this! At least things are moving forward, rather than standing still...

title: Support download of setup-files from private GitLab repositories
body:
It works fine for public repositories with anonymous access. For instance, a setup-file can be downloaded using such an URL https://gitlab.eclipse.org/eclipse/ease/ease/-/raw/main/releng/org.eclipse.ease.releng/oomph/ease.setup

But it doesn't work for private GitLab repositories.

It seems that GitLab doesn't support basic authentication. Here is [an open issue](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/19189).
And also basic authentication is not mentioned in the [documentation](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/administration/auth/).

So the following URL will not work:
https://gitlab.eclipse.org/eclipse/ease/ease/-/raw/main/releng/org.eclipse.ease.releng/oomph/ease.setup?oomph_basic_auth=true

GitLab will redirect to an HTML login form.

It's possible to clone a Git repository using ACCESS_TOKEN:
```
git clone https://oauth2:ACCESS_TOKEN@gitlab.eclipse.org/eclipse/ease/ease.git
```

But it seems that it's impossible to use such an URL to download a specific file.

Probably the only way to download a file from a private GitLab repository is to use [Files API](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/api/repository_files.html). In that case the followin URL should be used (you can ommit ACCESS_TOKEN if a repository allows anonymous access):
https://gitlab.eclipse.org/api/v4/projects/3814/repository/files/releng%2Forg.eclipse.ease.releng%2Foomph%2Fease.setup/raw?private_token=ACCESS_TOKEN

It works fine. But Eclipse Installer throws the following exception:

```
java.lang.ClassCastException: class org.eclipse.emf.ecore.xmi.impl.XMIResourceImpl cannot be cast to class org.eclipse.oomph.base.util.BaseResource (org.eclipse.emf.ecore.xmi.impl.XMIResourceImpl is in unnamed module of loader org.eclipse.osgi.internal.loader.EquinoxClassLoader @58dea0a5; org.eclipse.oomph.base.util.BaseResource is in unnamed module of loader org.eclipse.osgi.internal.loader.EquinoxClassLoader @7446d8d5)
        at org.eclipse.oomph.base.util.BaseUtil.loadResourceSafely(BaseUtil.java:97)
        at org.eclipse.oomph.setup.internal.installer.ProductPage$AddUserProductDialog.processResources(ProductPage.java:2073)
        at org.eclipse.emf.common.ui.dialogs.ResourceDialog.okPressed(ResourceDialog.java:372)
        at org.eclipse.jface.dialogs.Dialog.buttonPressed(Dialog.java:468)
        at org.eclipse.jface.dialogs.Dialog.lambda$0(Dialog.java:619)
        at org.eclipse.swt.events.SelectionListener$1.widgetSelected(SelectionListener.java:84)
        at org.eclipse.swt.widgets.TypedListener.handleEvent(TypedListener.java:252)
        at org.eclipse.swt.widgets.EventTable.sendEvent(EventTable.java:89)
        at org.eclipse.swt.widgets.Display.sendEvent(Display.java:5854)
        at org.eclipse.swt.widgets.Widget.sendEvent(Widget.java:1529)
        at org.eclipse.swt.widgets.Display.runDeferredEvents(Display.java:5064)
        at org.eclipse.swt.widgets.Display.readAndDispatch(Display.java:4516)
        at org.eclipse.jface.window.Window.runEventLoop(Window.java:823)
        at org.eclipse.jface.window.Window.open(Window.java:799)
        at org.eclipse.oomph.setup.internal.installer.ProductPage$15.widgetSelected(ProductPage.java:591)
        at org.eclipse.swt.widgets.TypedListener.handleEvent(TypedListener.java:252)
        at org.eclipse.swt.widgets.EventTable.sendEvent(EventTable.java:89)
        at org.eclipse.swt.widgets.Display.sendEvent(Display.java:5854)
        at org.eclipse.swt.widgets.Widget.sendEvent(Widget.java:1529)
        at org.eclipse.swt.widgets.Display.runDeferredEvents(Display.java:5064)
        at org.eclipse.swt.widgets.Display.readAndDispatch(Display.java:4516)
        at org.eclipse.oomph.setup.internal.installer.Installer.runEventLoop(Installer.java:359)
        at org.eclipse.oomph.setup.internal.installer.InstallerDialog.show(InstallerDialog.java:434)
        at org.eclipse.oomph.setup.internal.installer.InstallerApplication.run(InstallerApplication.java:295)
        at org.eclipse.oomph.setup.internal.installer.InstallerApplication.start(InstallerApplication.java:401)
        at org.eclipse.equinox.internal.app.EclipseAppHandle.run(EclipseAppHandle.java:208)
        at org.eclipse.core.runtime.internal.adaptor.EclipseAppLauncher.runApplication(EclipseAppLauncher.java:136)
        at org.eclipse.core.runtime.internal.adaptor.EclipseAppLauncher.start(EclipseAppLauncher.java:104)
        at org.eclipse.core.runtime.adaptor.EclipseStarter.run(EclipseStarter.java:402)
        at org.eclipse.core.runtime.adaptor.EclipseStarter.run(EclipseStarter.java:255)
        at java.base/jdk.internal.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke0(Native Method)
        at java.base/jdk.internal.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(NativeMethodAccessorImpl.java:77)
        at java.base/jdk.internal.reflect.DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.java:43)
        at java.base/java.lang.reflect.Method.invoke(Method.java:568)
        at org.eclipse.equinox.launcher.Main.invokeFramework(Main.java:651)
        at org.eclipse.equinox.launcher.Main.basicRun(Main.java:588)
        at org.eclipse.equinox.launcher.Main.run(Main.java:1459)
        at org.eclipse.equinox.launcher.Main.main(Main.java:1432)
```

I guess the cause is a wrong file name - raw (because the last segment of URL is raw). The file doesn't have setup extension.

It also seems that not all versions of GitLab returns correct HTTP headers:

```
Content-Disposition: inline; filename=blob
X-Gitlab-File-Name: ease.setup
```

`Content-Disposition` header should contain a valid file name.

Probably one of the ways to fix the problem is to register a Setup Resource Factory as a fallback one.

A discussion is available [here](https://www.eclipse.org/forums/index.php/m/1863380/).

title: NA
body: I'd personally be concerned about having my PAT visible in the file system, but that's the user's choice.  Better would be to find a way to prompt for credentials, store then in secure storage, and produce the appropriate request headers from that information...

title: NA
body:
An access token can be send in `Authorization` or `Private-Token` HTTP header:

```
curl --header 'Authorization: Bearer ACCESS_TOKEN' 'https://gitlab.eclipse.org/api/v4/projects/3814/repository/files/releng%2Forg.eclipse.ease.releng%2Foomph%2Fease.setup/raw'

curl --header 'Private-Token: ACCESS_TOKEN' 'https://gitlab.eclipse.org/api/v4/projects/3814/repository/files/releng%2Forg.eclipse.ease.releng%2Foomph%2Fease.setup/raw'
```

Maybe support of bearer authorization can be added in addition to basic authorization?

title: NA
body: Yes, that would be cool.   That being said, we are using ECF under the covers and the header stuff is handled in that technology stack so not so trivial to enhance.   Then there is also the problem of reproducibility.  I don't have access to a gitlab instance with a private repo where I can really properly test what's working and what isn't.  When I tried this stuff with gitlab.eclipse.org using a bogus/wrong token, it prompted me for credentials, though I did not try to enter any but rather created a proper token.  And finally, there is the problem of time investment, i.e., not having time.  😱

title: Setting multi-valued keys in git clone task
body:
### Discussed in https://github.com/orgs/eclipse-oomph/discussions/67
Originally posted by **joeshannon** February 13, 2024 Hi, We have configuration in our git clone tasks to add additional ref spec to a particular origin (for Gerrit purposes), it looks like: ![image](https://github.com/eclipse-oomph/oomph/assets/35498448/32b23012-2f24-428d-8be7-cd18e5a76581) A couple of weeks ago developers started noticing that the "Fetch from Gerrit..." option was not available anymore for newly provisioned workspaces. In the new git clones, only the first fetch refspec is added to the git repository config file instead of both of them. To be explicit, the relevant section in the config file looks like: ``` [remote "origin"] url = ssh://gerrit:29418/repo fetch = +refs/heads/*:refs/remotes/origin/* pushurl = ssh://gerrit:29418/repo push = HEAD:refs/for/main ``` Instead of: ``` [remote "origin"] url = ssh://gerrit:29418/repo fetch = +refs/heads/*:refs/remotes/origin/* fetch = refs/notes/*:refs/notes/* pushurl = ssh://gerrit:29418/repo push = HEAD:refs/for/main ``` I noted that there have been some changes to the git Oomph plugins recently so was wondering how we might achieve the previous behaviour?

title: NA
body:
Just had a little look at the change in more detail. The enhancement added two new parameters "force" and "recursive" to the configuration entries.

Using the "force" parameter does appear to restore the previous behaviour.

I'm not sure where that leaves this issue. I can't think of a better term than "force" but at the same time it's not entirely clear what the implications are especially for configs such as the fetch refspecs.

Perhaps this is a non-issue then, unless it is likely to affect many users that the default behaviour has changed?

title: NA
body: Thanks!  I’ll have a closer look too. The idea for force is to add/change the property only if not already present.  Perhaps multi properties are handled poorly in this regard.

title: NA
body:
I was trying to reproduce the problem like this:

![image](https://github.com/eclipse-oomph/oomph/assets/208716/26e175c4-218a-4bff-8a0c-3c229e812f2a)

But the multi-valued entry is populated:

![image](https://github.com/eclipse-oomph/oomph/assets/208716/db91f519-ba61-4758-a5ad-4325c50f1e8f)

It looks like probably you are trying to update the confirmation at the point in time when there is already a fetch property and indeed in that case an additional fetch config property will not be added except when there is a force.

The design intent is that one can specify properties in such a way that they do not change the user's configuration if the user has configured that already or differently.   Also the implementation was changed (improved) so that changes to the configuration will be applied by the git clone task when next performed (and makes it need to perform) whereas previously such changes were applied only when the clone is first created.  In addition, a new task was created that allows the user to apply configuration changes to arbitrary git clone tasks defined in setups, e.g., the following allows me to create an additional remote for my fork of some other arbitrary GitHub repository:

![image](https://github.com/eclipse-oomph/oomph/assets/208716/54a35119-2fb2-408a-92b1-efdd09a866eb)

Here I don't want to force the url property on the off chance that my fork's name is not the same as the original repository's name, e.g., if I clone such .github repository which each Eclipse GitHub organization has.

This is a long winded way of saying that I think it is working correctly as designed and it is an unfortunate side-effect that you now need to set the force property to get the old behavior.  I suppose I could change the default value to true, but I think it's more typically best to respect a user's existing configuration.

What do you think?

title: NA
body:
Thank you for the thorough assessment, and yes, I observe the same behaviour as above for an arbitrarily named property. 

To some extent it could be argued that certain properties should be considered as _not_ already set if the configuration is applied to a git clone task (rather than applied by the new git configuration task) as they haven't been specified explicitly in any Oomph setup task, but implicitly by EGit upon clone. However I don't know if this would provide a more intuitive or consistent approach overall (and it might not even be possible to implement).

The design description you have outlined above does make sense and I agree with the intent.

Possibly if there are some docs/hints/tips for the clone task it might be helpful to include something about these implicit/default Git/EGit config keys that will now require use of force?

title: NA
body:
Somewhere I should document this handy capability to augment each clone task such that it creates an additional remote for your fork of the repository being cloned.  Use Navigate -> Open Setup -> User, copy the text below and paste it to the `User` node:
```
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<git:GitConfigurationTask
    xmi:version="2.0"
    xmlns:xmi="http://www.omg.org/XMI"
    xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"
    xmlns:git="http://www.eclipse.org/oomph/setup/git/1.0"
    xsi:schemaLocation="http://www.eclipse.org/oomph/setup/git/1.0 https://raw.githubusercontent.com/eclipse-oomph/oomph/master/setups/models/Git.ecore"
    remoteURIPattern="(?:https://github.com/|git@github.com:)[^/]*(?<!merks)(/.*)">
  <configSections
      name="remote">
    <subsections
        name="merks">
      <properties
          key="fetch"
          value="+refs/heads/*:refs/remotes/merks/*"
          force="true"/>
      <properties
          key="url"
          value="git@github.com:merks$1"/>
    </subsections>
  </configSections>
</git:GitConfigurationTask>
```
Of course you should change "merks" to your GitHub account id.

title: NA
body:
To also match the _HTTPS_ URL (in case you're **not** cloning with SSH), use this `remoteURIPattern` instead (shamelessly taken from @merks E-Mail 😁 ) which will match both HTTPS and SSH.

```
remoteURIPattern="(?:https://(?:merks@)?github.com/|git@github.com:)[^/]*(?<!/merks)(/.*)"
```

And if you want to use HTTPS instead of SSH in your remote, **replace** the `url` property:
```
<properties
          key="url"
          value="https://github.com/merks$1"/>
```

As usual: replace `merks` with your own GitHub account ID.

Thank you once again for the help, Ed! 🚀 💪

title: NA
body: Thanks for reporting this one, my team encountered it and updating and using `force` has solved it

title: NA
body: I dislike when new features break old things, but sometimes that's challenging.  ☹

title: Manual tasks not executed after restart due to installation changes
body: If I invoke "Perform Setup Tasks..." and the Manual Tasks to be executed require a restart (e.g. P2 changes), the remaining Manual Tasks are not executed after the restart.

title: NA
body: Now that you mention it, I think I ran into that today myself, but with all the multi-tasking I didn't pay so much attention.  Maybe it's related to the new restart behavior of the Platform...

title: NA
body:
I just observed this with Eclipe 2022-06.
Also had this earlier - don't know which versions.

title: NA
body: That's very old.   So more likely something in Oomph itself then...

title: NA
body:
Btw - "Skip automatic task execution at startup time" in preferences is disabled.
I guess, even if this is enabled, in case of a "Perform Setup Tasks..." manual invocation, it should be ignored if a restart is involved.

title: NA
body:
I remote debugged this and it works for me.  I use this simple way to reproduce the problem:

![image](https://github.com/eclipse-oomph/oomph/assets/208716/fabe0367-7bb8-43cf-a1b4-312dff59ed11)

I.e., the modifying the eclipse.ini will require a restart and then the string substitution task should run on restart.  And I can change the values so that both tasks are needed again.

With remote debug I can see that it's all working properly it should.

![image](https://github.com/eclipse-oomph/oomph/assets/208716/c2cb32b8-9778-4227-90e8-e444b32905ca)

And yes, if there is a restart file the preference to skip startup tasks is ignored:

![image](https://github.com/eclipse-oomph/oomph/assets/208716/ce4e406a-b87f-4fc4-93df-e1b893baf4b4)

So I don't know how to proceed without being able to reproduce the problem. 

Maybe there is something in the error log indicating some type of failure?

title: NA
body:
I can reproduce with the [attached setup](https://github.com/eclipse-oomph/oomph/files/14496792/Test70.setup.txt). It contains:

- an Eclipse Ini Task to trigger restart (modified by a user variable)
- a Maven Update Task (set to MANUAL only)
- a Launch Task (set to STARTUP MANUAL with "run every startup"=false)
- a Projects Build Task (set to STARTUP MANUAL)

After initial installation, run "Perform Setup Tasks", go back in the wizard and change value of "foo" and proceed with all Manual Tasks selected.
My results:

- 2022-06 (Oomph also ~2022-06): MANUAL and STARTUP tasks are triggered after restart as expected ✔️ 
- 2022-12 / 2023-03 / 2023-06 / 2024-03: nothing is executed after restart due to changed eclipse.ini ❌ 

Note that the latter all get the following installed:
Oomph Setup	1.31.0.v20240211-0940
Oomph Setup Launching	1.18.0.v20230617-1322

Nothing suspicious in the logs.

title: NA
body:
I could reproduce this problem, but I get the sense it's reproducible because of how I am testing:

![image](https://github.com/eclipse-oomph/oomph/assets/208716/ea0ae8cd-c82e-40ba-9da8-2b18db9534f3)

It's comparing the URIs of the things to be restarted against the URI of the task in the performer.  

So I wonder if something like that is happening in your case too, i.e., some funky redirections or maybe even your own index.

In any case, I will try to add some logic that will hopefully generally fix such an issue.

title: NA
body:

This takes about an hour to complete (because mac notarization of the installers takes really long).

I must build the final 1.32 release today for contribution to SimRel 2024-03 later today...

Would you be able to test that this actually fixes the problem for you after the build is completed?

```
Be sure that the installed bundle `org.eclipse.oomph.setup.ui` has today's timestamp for the version qualifier.   

If you don't have time, what's there now will be what's in the final release.

title: Behavior of variables is not correct, when used in a filter condition
body: A VariablesTask, which is defined conditionally, is always executed, if the variable is used in a filter condition. _**Example:**_ In this example ([org.eclipse.setup.zip](https://github.com/eclipse-oomph/oomph/files/14791180/org.eclipse.setup.zip)) the `my.feature1` and `my.feature2` are enabled depending on the setting of `my.version`. When selecting the `S1` stream, then no feature should be active. But as shown on the confirmation page, the `my.feature1` was enabled. That's because it is used in the filter of the CompoundTask `Feature1`. The `my.feature2` behaves correctly. I assume, the issue is located in [SetupTaskPerformer.getSetupTasks()](https://github.com/eclipse-oomph/oomph/blob/2ff4b6b6feeca7992c509db81bea11f33b9d60f9/plugins/org.eclipse.oomph.setup.core/src/org/eclipse/oomph/setup/internal/core/SetupTaskPerformer.java#L1717) in the lines [1734-1742](https://github.com/eclipse-oomph/oomph/blob/2ff4b6b6feeca7992c509db81bea11f33b9d60f9/plugins/org.eclipse.oomph.setup.core/src/org/eclipse/oomph/setup/internal/core/SetupTaskPerformer.java#L1734-L1742). There all VariableTasks, which are used in a filter, are added unconditionally. Maybe this section could simply be removed?

title: NA
body:
Of course it all works well when Feature1 is disabled:

![image](https://github.com/eclipse-oomph/oomph/assets/208716/b6df0c5e-1334-4386-9736-da87d7273c53)

That code cannot simply be removed.  It was added when support for conditional tasks was added:

https://github.com/eclipse-oomph/oomph/commit/1db9130d4f07899319df833c8f80346c746c862b

The support for conditional tasks is super tricky because nothing is actually executed in a flow control style.  Rather tasks are gathered, where the conditions affect was gathered and what is not gathered.  

You can imagine having a filter expression on some compound C1 that sets some variable to a particular value and that variable is then being used in a filter on some compound C2 that conditionally sets the value of a variable that alters outcome of the filter on C1.  E.g., here is a non-nonsensical usage where Feature1, when my.feature1=true, will set my.version=1 which implies that my.feature.1 should be set to false by V1, which then implies Feature1's condition is false:

![image](https://github.com/eclipse-oomph/oomph/assets/208716/d602a88f-7d20-4a73-a8d0-c58f1f33bac5)

You can see how this just becomes circular when there is no order of execution.

So using the value of a variable that is conditionally set elsewhere as a filter variable is just not workable because there isn't really any flow control. 

Probably you have a bigger example where this is just a small demonstrator, but somehow you must find a different or better way.

title: NA
body:
Ok, I understand.

There is already a cycle detection, when the variables are expanded (see `SetupCoreUtil.reorder` used in `SetupTaskPerformer.reorderVariables`). Maybe that could be extended to support the filters?

title: NA
body:
This is super fragile code such that touching it is likely to have surprising consequences.  Also, my time is super limited for adding addressing something complicated that I suspect cannot be made to work properly.

Is this something you want to invest your time in trying to fix in Oomph itself via a contribution, or might your time be better invested in finding a way not to rely on conditionally initialized variables being used as a filter for other conditional task?

title: NA
body: I'll find a way to don't rely on conditionally initialized variables. Thanks.

title: NA
body:
@stegeto22 

Sorry about that and thank you for your understanding.   I could go on and on about how swamped I am, but that's my problem not yours...

Could you please try the instructions at this link to repair the bundle pool?

https://github.com/eclipse-oomph/oomph/issues/60#issuecomment-1888648461

I'd really appreciate if you let me know whether or not that helps solve the problem!

title: NA
body:
Thank you for sharing the important details.  This appears to be a network problem.  Is the URL https://download.eclipse.org/oomph/updates/milestone/latest/ accessible in your browser like this:

![image](https://github.com/eclipse-oomph/oomph/assets/208716/acc3dd02-adbf-4c8d-ba05-159fb6c6cf2b)

The repository definitely loads (for me):

![image](https://github.com/eclipse-oomph/oomph/assets/208716/c8ec11cc-a052-43f8-99db-1acfea99b64b)

What can you tell me about your network configuration?  I.e., is there a firewall that might be restricting access?

Note that you can download a zip file from here if your network allows that:

- https://www.eclipse.org/downloads/packages/
- https://www.eclipse.org/downloads/download.php?file=/technology/epp/downloads/release/2024-03/R/eclipse-jee-2024-03-R-win32-x86_64.zip

Note also though that you will not be able to perform updates or install new software with such an installation because the IDE application uses the same network access infrastructure as is used by the installer application so if the latter doesn't work, the former won't either, but at least you'll have a functional installation.

title: NA
body: I think I can't help further with network problems.

title: Show location of current Oomph setup
body:
![image](https://github.com/eclipse-oomph/oomph/assets/3389524/88c263c6-71dd-4c00-b8cf-7a836ab67974)

At our company, we use different Oomph files. Sometimes, we use the local one in our git repo (in one of our multiple clones), sometimes one that is uploaded to some server, and sometimes a local one to workaround some issues. The current setup (see above) doesn't show you which of these is selected, forcing you to remove the current one and add the one you need to ensure you have the right one.

title: NA
body:
Did you know about this control's details?

![image](https://github.com/eclipse-oomph/oomph/assets/208716/51784e2c-47a0-40cf-9372-424ab3f8643f)

You can see the information about the location of a setup is really quite a long string in the normal/standard case where the catalog is loaded via the setups zip.  What specifically are you hoping to see and where are you hoping to see it?  Perhaps the full URI in the hover over the product?

title: NA
body:
I wasn't aware of that menu, but it also doesn't show the path I would expect. I'd like to know where the source of `Eclipse IDE for Sigasi Developers` is. Sometimes it is `~/Downloads/SigasiEclipse.setup`, sometimes it'll be `~/sigasi-development/git/SigasiEclipse.setup`, and other times it might be `sigasi.com/SigasiEclipse.setup`. Showing this path on a hover would solve the issue. Personally, I was thinking of a second part in the same row, like JDT's outline: the `byte[]` for `value`

![image](https://github.com/eclipse-oomph/oomph/assets/3389524/2a3311a7-d49e-453c-9328-c2faa33a4b73)

title: NA
body:
Keep in mind though that these URLs in generally are REALLY RIDICULOUSLY LONG:

![image](https://github.com/eclipse-oomph/oomph/assets/208716/d2ff761d-4f16-494b-bfa1-5335c74f15f6)

I would not want to see that pushed into everyone's face in general everywhere.

On the project page (where similar location concerns might arise), we do show hover information in general:

![image](https://github.com/eclipse-oomph/oomph/assets/208716/c19f2579-f745-49f3-8286-9f1378bce396)

But for products we show information about the product directly in the info field based on the selection.

Somehow I'd like to do something that's not so constantly in-your-face for everyone when very few would really want that or would want it only occasionally/rarely...

title: NA
body: Hovers are fine. I suppose our URLs are shorter since we point directly to a `.setup` file, not as part of a zip

title: NA
body:
The hovers have the problem that the long URLs don't display well because the hover box is not very big.  So I added a control to determine whether to show link information or not.

![image](https://github.com/eclipse-oomph/oomph/assets/208716/f0cb5331-e9a1-4959-9412-9d3256f4f54b)

I show link information only if the object is directly contained by a resource, so only the two catalogs show the details.  The tool item's state is persistent.  It's disabled by default.  I show both the direct URI of the resource as sell as the resolved URI, if it is different.

The project page has the same control:

![image](https://github.com/eclipse-oomph/oomph/assets/208716/f91da213-4707-4865-9b16-a3d6622a6eb4)

I've shortened the very long archive: URIs to show only the location of the archive.

title: NA
body:
Thanks for the very quick fix @merks Testing it out, it does exactly what I need it to do. It's now very clear which URI is used. I do see now what you mean by long URIs though.

![image](https://github.com/eclipse-oomph/oomph/assets/3389524/1d369a46-4b84-4c41-b3bc-1d4b1a1efdde)

title: NA
body: I should add some special logic for user-ext scheme to show less detail. I think only the resolved location is of interest…. What do you think?

title: NA
body: Yes that seems like a good addition

title: Filtering Oomph in the preference view only shows introduction page
body:
When you search for `Oomph` in the preference file, you will see the following:

![image](https://github.com/eclipse-oomph/oomph/assets/3389524/bf902ac4-663c-4c1c-b393-f23589ca5e43)

This is quite annoying as I now cannot access the tree anymore. Comparing to other plugins, normally, you see the entire expanded tree:

![image](https://github.com/eclipse-oomph/oomph/assets/3389524/4d3aa46d-f44b-42f8-934f-eb38fd9ee816)

title: NA
body: How would one fix/change that?  I've been annoyed by that too!

title: NA
body: Sadly, I don't know without hopping into the code, but seeing how other plugins can do it, it must be some misconfiguration, or there must be a workaround. It works fine for MWE2, Xtext, SonarLint, M2E, etc.

title: NA
body: Tested it, works perfectly, thanks for the very quick fix @merks

title: NA
body: I'm happy to be able to locate things more quickly myself too.   👍

body:

title: NA
body: I'm really not sure why so often folks open an issue and then simply never follow on it.  I'll assume this addresses the problem.  Newer versions of the installer will detected missing jars such that a subsequent attempt to install will download the artifact again.

title: NA
body:
I assume you are inside a corporate firewall, correct?   Such PKIX exceptions are generally caused because the certificate used in the network traffic is not rooted on a certificate in the JDK/JRE's cacerts and firewalls often inject certificates into the network traffic.  

The options I mentioned are intended to make the running Java application use Windows own cacerts.

So I wonder, are you able to access this page in a browser?

https://download.eclipse.org/justj/jres/21/updates/release/latest/

I guess so...

If your firewall is blocking in interfering with the traffic you might be forced to just download a zip file from here instead:

https://www.eclipse.org/downloads/packages/

title: OOmph uses outdated JDK path after JDK update
body:
After JDK updates itself i always run into several error, because Eclipse Adoptium's path changes after update.
So after eclipse stopped working (which is understandable) i tried to setup a fresh OOmmphed workspace. But it kept using the outdated path for "JRE 17 Location"
I had to manually "Show all variables" and change the JDK location.
![image](https://github.com/eclipse-oomph/oomph/assets/51790620/8ddbb2c5-c15e-43b1-9cf1-990e7e95dbac)
surprisingly Oomph seems to know that the old version does not exists anymore (was not selectable as JVM) but still auto-selected it by default :-(
In such a case it would be nice if OOmph would automatically select a valid path only or actively asks about a valid location.

body:

![image](https://github.com/eclipse-oomph/oomph/assets/208716/402c05f9-804e-46b9-889a-14d69cf55d0b)

One cannot generally know that some task will not create the specified folder while performing...

title: NA
body: This is why I never use the JDK installers because I really can't abide the potential have having ~100 installations become broken.  Of course that's no consolation to those who do.  Also, because folks don't generally read information that's presented to them, I'm not sure how to prompt a user to update the JRE location.  E.g., isNeeded could return true when the JRE folder doesn't actually exist and then the task could fail with a message saying the JRE folder doesn't exist.  But how to get the user to actual fix it, i.e., go to the variables page and show all variables and change the value.  Or edit the user setup?

title: NA
body:
(I am going back and forth on this...)

My current thought is this isn't that useful because the people who are affected won't get this window (Either the IDE fails to start, or it doesn't update the components that make it into a new version)

But if you think enough people will see it (colleagues, installs of older version that display the same warning, etc) then go for it.

title: NA
body: Yes, it's true that if the IDE is already started, when folks do the check-for-updates, then those folks won't see this.   So the closer to the actual release date this updated in the catalog and is shown to users, the fewer people for whom it will be useful.  That said, it's often the case that there are partial updates and then after the restart this would be shown.   It's quite a bit of work to get this worded in a way that make sense and is actually helpful and that time could well be invested in something more useful.  So I too man back and forth on this.

title: NA
body: Sounds like enough people will see it. Go for it! It can be updated easily enough later.

title: NA
body:
Hi! 
I understand the context and importance of the warning, and it's true that people often overlook important information if they assume it doesn't apply to them.

While the headline "_If you don't read this, **bad things** will happen_" certainly grabs attention, it might be too alarmist and could cause unnecessary anxiety among users. It is not trust building. (At least that was the impression in our team when some of us got this message...)

Ideally, this message should only appear (within the IDE...) when someone encounters an issue using an unsupported Java version. If the warning is relevant and timely, it is more likely to be read and understood. Is something like this possible?

In the meantime: A headline should be urgent but also informative and reassuring. Something more balanced like "_Important Update: Please Read to Avoid Issues_" would convey urgency while maintaining a professional tone. We could also dive into more details and write something like "_Important information for users who rely on a JDK older than Java 21_" or "_Important update: Read carefully if you rely on a JDK older than Java 21_".

What do you think?

PS: I understand that the alternative (users complaining on X about their Eclipse not working) is even less in our best interest. So, thank you for addressing the issue and taking care of it!

title: NA
body:
This is generally caused when you are behind a firewall, that firewall injects a certificates into the network traffic, and that certificate are not rooted in one of the root cacerts of the JRE.

Have you ever had to add keys to your Java's installation's cacerts?   Maybe the cacerts of the JRE installed on your system have been updated.  

You can get installers **without** an embedded JRE here and these will use the default JRE of your system.

https://download.eclipse.org/justj/?file=oomph/epp/2024-06/R

I.e., these two:

![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/bb3a8a09-c40f-4afe-8918-027e8176553a)

You can also download a package:

https://www.eclipse.org/downloads/packages/

But you will not be able to update or installer new software on these for exactly the same reason.

The certificate chain can viewed in a browser and can be export to *.pem so that one can use keytool.exe -import -alias some-alias cacerts -file xyz.pem to add it to each JDK's cacerts.  I had to do this last month for a client.    I hope I remember how to do it the next time.  Google this:
```
java add certificate to cacert
```

title: Possible duplicate installations items
body:
Using the installer's Advanced Mode and selecting Eclipse Platform to start from a minimal installation, the resulting Eclipse looks like:

![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/1e070010-c680-4cb1-8e99-34f2d99875cc)

As can be seen, there are multiple items listed, but some already appear as subitems of others. `Eclipse RCP` and `feature.group Eclipse Platform` are both subitems in `ide Eclipse Platform` and individual items.

By trial and error, I uninstalled the "extra" items and got to

![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/a9788317-9f92-4e05-9958-bababe29db7d)

This looks more correct to me. Is there a reason duplicate entries are added? Oomph can also be removed to reach the minimal platform, at least when bundles are not used.

title: NA
body:
Not really an Oomph question.  The reason is that the roots of the tree are the things directly installed into the IDE, the so-called user roots.  The content under them are things (features) includes included by those features, recursively.

The installer will generally always install Oomph because that's what's specified in the catalogs:

![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/e60d164f-00ec-4665-878f-1474a9c502fc)

It is possible to define your own product catalog:

https://wiki.eclipse.org/Eclipse_Oomph_Authoring#Hosting_your_own_index_.2F_catalogs

title: NA
body:
> Not really an Oomph question. The reason is that the roots of the tree are the things directly installed into the IDE, the so-called user roots. The content under them are things (features) includes included by those features, recursively.

But from the installer I only installed Eclipse Platform, not the other 2 items, why would they be installed separately?

title: NA
body:
I assume you installed this:

![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/b79282d9-211d-4101-b1fc-5f0f88fcfd43)

I think you're going to need to understand the models involved. You can use Navigate -> Open Setup -> Parent Models -> Catalog Index Eclipse to see all the models, unless of course you've uninstalled Oomph.

I get the sense you are fussing over things that don't really matter.  In any case, if you want a define a product that is exactly and only exactly like you want it, you will have to define it yourself.

You can even go so far as to literally define a *.product file and use Tycho to build it (just like Oomph does for the Installer Product.)   

This folder contains a minimal example:

https://github.com/eclipse-justj/justj.tools/tree/master/products/org.eclipse.justj.tools.sample.product

It's not really up-to-date with the latest bundle start level details:

https://github.com/eclipse-platform/eclipse.platform.releng.aggregator/blob/24cf67167e4196fffd312bfe4d5a4a230a3c8b18/eclipse.platform.releng.tychoeclipsebuilder/eclipse.platform.repository/sdk.product#L190-L198

title: NA
body:
> I assume you installed this:

![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/79c4e1eb-1e59-4fed-804c-6be21fca5e0e)

I installed the selected item - Eclipse Platform. The image you posted is also what I see if I go to the catalog.

> I think you're going to need to understand the models involved. You can use Navigate -> Open Setup -> Parent Models -> Catalog Index Eclipse to see all the models, unless of course you've uninstalled Oomph.

Yes, I do need to understand this.

> I get the sense you are fussing over things that don't really matter. In any case, if you want a define a product that is exactly and only exactly like you want it, you will have to define it yourself.

My goal is rather simple: create a minimal Eclipse on which I can install what I need.
Usually we are told that https://download.eclipse.org/eclipse/downloads/ contains the basic Eclipse package, without the prepared packages ("for Java developers", "for C/C++ developers", "for Web developers"...), but I found this to not really be the case just by going on adventures with the components. This link downloads the Eclipse SDK, which is also geared towards plugin developers and developers of the platform itself. If I look at its installation details, I see:

* ECF ... Developer Resources items
* Plugin Development Environment items
* EMF ... Developer Resources items
* Other development resources

I'd venture a guess that most Eclipse users don't need these because they don't write plugins or develop the platform. I could be wrong about this analysis. However, after installing the minimal Eclipse Platform + JDT I get what looks to me like a completely functional environment that is *less than twice the size and loads more than twice faster* than the one in the link above. Of course, then a run-of-the-mill developer might need to add some Mavan/Gradle plugins, Git integration and other common plugins like that.

> You can even go so far as to literally define a *.product file and use Tycho to build it (just like Oomph does for the Installer Product.)

This is what I was looking at, and I might do. It will basically be the Platform + JDT, which is a skinnier version of the SDK from the link.

body:
Given a choice between the following:

1. An single "complex" implementation used uniformly throughout the framework that works on all platforms.
2. An additional  new "simpler" implementation used only for the simple installer and is created simply because the existing implementation doesn't work macos for reasons unknown.

I'd much rather see the reasons unknown become known so that Oomph's support on macos is generally improved via option 1.

Yes, drag-and-drop is used elsewhere, e.g, on advanced installer titles and in their tree views, and of course generally in the Oomph editors.  The main complexity with drag and drop is that while Windows provides early information about what is being dragged from where to where, the other platforms generally have those details only at the end when the drop happens.

I expect the code to get here when the drop happens:

![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/03982edf-dbc2-4b72-ad81-2f69aecd0e2e)

Probably for macos the dragAndDropCommandInformation is null, which I simulated on Windows by setting it to null in the debugger.  It ends up creating a load resource command and when that executes, that's what's used to by to drive the dialogs:

![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/bb5c552b-29dc-453a-8fd0-079bc6536715)

So I'd like this to work on macos but not by creating a new different implementation for a single use case but by fixing the current one used throughout the framework.

```
https://www.eclipse.org/setups/installer/?url=https://raw.githubusercontent.com/eclipse-platform/eclipse.platform.ui/master/releng/org.eclipse.ui.releng/platformUIConfiguration.setup&show=true
Auto-launch Eclipse Installer
```
Dragging the Drag Link... doesn't work, and here we see the native transfer is yielding a URL with a line break character in it:
```
![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/9c179119-0242-48ac-ac6e-bd47e8c5ed5e)
```
I can "repair" such a thing in Oomph, but it seems to me that the native transfer is wrong or unhelpful, but at least there is data that could be processed.

Dragging the image does not produce a URL transfer at all:

![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/cff278ca-3a12-46d0-b245-d91b940547a1)

Dragging and dropping it onto a text editor opens a new editor with stuff in it that looks like the contents of the page:

![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/fe992ea8-48cc-42c7-977a-6f46c13ee6e7)

When I look at all the native transfers being called in OomphTransferDelegate I don't see any of those return something useful for this case.   So it just doesn't appear that dragging that thing is like dragging a link as far as SWT is concerned.

Probably macos has similar problems. 

The places to look are in org.eclipse.oomph.internal.ui.OomphTransferDelegate where nativeToJava is being called to get the dragged contents out of the native layer.

If you can instrument this code and provide details about what the framework seems coming out of the transfer layer, that would be very helpful to try to get at least some of these working...

![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/2c97549d-7936-4051-87f7-15f88b1177dd)
