title: Applying a configuration with a project in a fresh environment requires a pre-installed JDK
body:
When applying an Oomph configuration, which contains an installation and workspace with product and project in a completely clean environment, one is asked to specify the path to a JDK and there is no way to omit specifying one.

This means that one needs to install a JDK manually before the application of the configuration can be completed. This is unfortunate since Oomph actually will install a JDK, usually of a matching or even higher version.
On workaround might be to install just the product and to apply the configuration then later.

But ideally by default the installer would just use the JDK to be installed by Oomph. This could maybe be done by setting the future path of the to be installed JDK and ignoring that it doesn't exist yet.
Of course if a user wants to this variable should still be overidable.

If you know a better strategy to solve this or have some pointers where to start, I can look into solving this.

![grafik](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/40761c58-08d9-44e1-8a85-18cdefeb105b)

title: NA
body:
This Browse... button is now enabled also when used for the property field on the Variables page:

![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/7cd4aadf-2360-4765-82ab-45366d39c95c)

It's been enhanced to open a filtered view of the available adoptium downloads:

https://adoptium.net/temurin/releases/?os=windows&arch=x64&version=17

---

There is no general knowledge about a future location of a JRE/JDK.  Which JDK is used to run the installation is generally unrelated to the JRE configured in the IDE and it can and is selected in different ways.  If one chooses a JDK on the machine, then the dialog/selection will not be empty.  If one chooses a JustJ JRE, we don't know the exact version and hence the location until looking in the p2 repository. Of course one could also just not have a JRE task at all and end up with an IDE where there is only a JRE corresponding to the one running the installation.  Having a JRE that's specifically a Java 17 JRE because that's what's currently targeted seems like  a good thing, even if the IDE itself is running with Java 21.  I expect that folks who will be contributing to enhancing the Eclipse IDE's complex frameworks will have an easy time installing Java...

title: MyLynQueriesTask is breaking the installation of Eclipse versions using MyLyn >=4.0.0 P2 feature names (like e.g. Eclipse 2024-03)
body:
**Issue:**
If my setups contain a `MyLynQueriesTask` and I am using an Eclipse version being configured for MyLyn 4.0.0+ P2 feature names, then the installer runs into unresovable P2 feature dependency conflicts.
In this case I did use **Eclipse 2024-03** for the setup.

**Root cause assumed**
The current [MyLyn.ecore](https://github.com/eclipse-oomph/oomph/blob/45a33a82ae2235a2486c19872fcb7e4fef632b73/setups/models/Mylyn.ecore#L22)  is defining feature `org.eclipse.mylyn.bugzilla_feature.feature.group`  for the `MyLynQueriesTask`. This feature name is not provided by MyLyn >=4.0.0 anymore as far as I can see. MyLyn did change the feature names with MyLyn 4.0.0 versus MyLyn 3.x.

**Workaround**
When I change the MyLyn features of the Eclipse product setup definitions using MyLyn 4+ feature names to optional, then the installation did work.

**Solution Proposal**
Remove or make the feature dependency `org.eclipse.mylyn.bugzilla_feature.feature.group` optional for `MyLynQueriesTask` installableUnits to be agnostic regarding the MyLyn version coming with Eclipse platform or being used by custom setups.

@merks
As far as I see the MyLyn features did "continuously" migrate from MyLyn 3.x to 4.x features within the following Eclipse product setups (checked for IDE for Java Developers only):
**2023-06**: MyLyn **3.x** features only
**2023-09**: MyLyn **4.x** features non optional, MyLyn **3.x** features **optional**
**2023-12**: MyLyn **4.x** features only, all MyLyn **3.x** named features **removed** - **except** `org.eclipse.mylyn.wikitext_feature.feature.group`
**2024-03**: MyLyn **4.x** features only, `org.eclipse.mylyn.wikitext.feature.feature.group` **added**, `org.eclipse.mylyn.wikitext_feature.feature.group` set to **optional**
**2024-06**: MyLyn **4.x** features only, `org.eclipse.mylyn.wikitext_feature.feature.group` **removed**
**2024-09**: same as 2024-06

body:
It seems you are just repeating yourself:

https://github.com/eclipse-packaging/packages/issues/230

But now it looks like you're failing to download artifacts without the PKIX:
```
javax.net.ssl.SSLHandshakeException: PKIX path building failed: sun.security.provider.certpath.SunCertPathBuilderException: unable to find valid certification path to requested target
```
But it looks like lots of artifacts were downloaded before a bunch of them failed.

Yes, of not uncommon that virus scanners will cause problems by locking files such they after downloading they can't be moved to their final location.

If you try again,  the pool should slowly fill up such that you can run to completion.

title: Prepare for the termination of  Eclipse User Storage Service
body:
Oomph's Preference Synchronizer uses the deprecated `Eclipse.org` service:

![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/d8b2449e-b208-410e-ab5b-10717bb4163c)

The planned termination for this services is for July of this year:

https://gitlab.eclipse.org/eclipsefdn/helpdesk/-/issues/4696#note_2340773

While it's possible in principle to provide some alternative mechanism for storage sharing, it's not clear whether there is any real demand for that.  At this point we simply plan to **remove this support and all code related to it** from Oomph.

The plan is to present this **non-modal** dialog to the user if they have the service enabled:

![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/23e7f618-4ca6-4b08-b0e2-44ed0644ad4a)

This enables the user to easily disable the use of the service, or to continue to use the service.   If the user chooses the latter, they will be reminded again (via this dialog) after a week has elapsed.  The dialog includes a link to this issue so users can find out more details and can comment on this issue if they wish to do so.

---

I instrumented a fake service that throws exceptions for all methods.  Mostly these are silently ignored, sometimes with logged exceptions.   If one tries to record a preference and share it with the remote service:

![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/2552307d-06aa-407a-a03a-44a49d43bd43)

that will display a failure:

![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/be8e969b-30b6-4442-9076-b46130374b6b)

title: NA
body:
> While it's possible in principle to provide some alternative mechanism for storage sharing, it's not clear whether there is any real demand for that.

If there is no storage sharing, how can the preferences sync?

title: NA
body:
Since both the libraries for the service, i.e., https://gitlab.eclipse.org/eclipse/usssdk/org.eclipse.usssdk, as well as the Eclipse.org service itself are being removed, I really don't see much in the way of alternatives that could work for everyone out of the box.

I just wanted to double check that there isn't a misunderstanding:  Preferences can still be recorded and will still be applied uniformly to every workspace, they just can't be stored in a central location and subsequently shared across multiple machines anymore.  They're stored here in the home folder of the user's account on any give machine and that will continue to function well:

![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/fbe4d634-3751-4db1-9c02-31dd3e8dafe6)

Perhaps someone will want this capability enough to contribute toward an alternative implementation.  Unfortunately my capacity for providing that is very limited...

title: NA
body: I use this feature and like to have it or something like this in the future.

title: Oomph startup tasks fails with `Bundle pool <pool path> could not be loaded`
body:
Following a completely fresh install of an Oomph provisioned IDE (i.e. no `~/.p2`, `~/.eclipse`, or any install folders were pre-existing), if a new feature is added to the oomph profile to be rolled out for all IDEs (say a couple of days after install & users using their IDE), the oomph startup task will fail on the next Eclipse startup with `Bundle pool <pool path> could not be loaded`.
If a user simply presses `Back`, and then clicks `Finish` to restart the setup tasks, it then works. After that, the error never appears again if more features are added to the Oomph profile. I've seen this happen for all OSes.

Users are usually oblivious that this is happening, this is the only indication that something is going wrong:

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/d2648ca7-57bb-4c75-a297-669f4d78872a)

This is the error presented: 

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/a0008752-f20a-4afa-8a5f-fe6d06032257)

Clicking back gets everyone to this dialog, if they click finish, its then works:

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/6d22ca9a-657d-41fd-8407-d8d01ea7b664)

I've seen this for a long time, but its been OK to just tell people to click back & forwards. Though its causing a few issues now with rolling out plugin upgrades and people not being upgraded & things breaking, or getting new preferences we're setting. I thought I'd at least report it, even though I appreciate it might be a tricky one to diagnose. Perhaps its known?

We're using:

- Eclipse Installer 1.35.0 Build 900
- org.eclipse.oomph.setup.feature.group & org.eclipse.oomph.preferences.feature.group from https://download.eclipse.org/oomph/drops/release/1.34.0-a/

I've just tried to recreate this using the latest plugins from https://download.eclipse.org/oomph/updates/milestone/latest, but the problem still remains. Perhaps its the installer, I'm not sure.

title: NA
body:
I really do test such things a often.   It's quite easy to test such scenarios with these two VM arguments:

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/9fa9a3db-cad8-4460-aa34-d6521b3cdadf)

This will run the installer in that "new user home" and the installation will have the option to also run in that new user home:

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/421c0f34-5a0e-4065-a632-bb8a3452e4cf)

Have you looked in the Error Log view for clues? 

I really need a series of steps that I can follow that will lead to this error.  I don't have any kind of theory for why this would happen and I've never ever seen this happen.  Hopefully the Error log has clues...

title: NA
body:
No real clues, just the same info as the other dialog really I think?

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/86882f49-5e92-460f-bfa2-c0abf53a1e5e)

title: NA
body:
I don't really know what an artifactRepository is supposed to represent in this context, so I've zero right to make any guesses but I'm assuming all the feature/plugins and the artifacts.xml under the pool folder. Perhaps the error is a bit of a red herring, it seems to be falling over on [this line](https://github.com/eclipse-oomph/oomph/blob/d33905a0958ab4d952d352eb5ccff5b54844e430/plugins/org.eclipse.oomph.p2.core/src/org/eclipse/oomph/p2/internal/core/BundlePoolImpl.java#L150), which means its just tried to run `createRepository()` at my pool location, and that location should (and does) exist as the IDE will be using that pool already ?
Should it have not found it on [this line](https://github.com/eclipse-oomph/oomph/blob/d33905a0958ab4d952d352eb5ccff5b54844e430/plugins/org.eclipse.oomph.p2.core/src/org/eclipse/oomph/p2/internal/core/BundlePoolImpl.java#L133)? This is of course if artifactRepositoryManager has an entry for it? Maybe it doesn't, and the act of going back & clicking finish populates it again? (......again, I'm guessing! I'm not sure how I could step through this as my Oomph IDE starts )

title: NA
body:
So the exception that is thrown here but is discarded would be the one with more helpful details:

https://github.com/eclipse-oomph/oomph/blob/d33905a0958ab4d952d352eb5ccff5b54844e430/plugins/org.eclipse.oomph.p2.core/src/org/eclipse/oomph/p2/internal/core/BundlePoolImpl.java#L138

Probably the create fails because the repository exists, but even for that we throw away the exception too, none of which is helpful for determining anything about the reason for failure.

This definitely should be improved.

---

Another useful option for the installer is `-Doomph.setup.remote.debug=maybe`.  Then in the eclipse.ini of the installation it will contain this:
```
-DDoomph.setup.remote.debug=true
-DXdebug
-DXrunjdwp:transport=dt_socket,server=y,suspend=n,address=8123
```
Then I can easily change it to this later:
```
-Doomph.setup.remote.debug=true
-Xdebug
-Xrunjdwp:transport=dt_socket,server=y,suspend=n,address=8123
```
Of course you can copy and paste that form this issue as well now.  Because of `-Doomph.setup.remote.debug=true` the IDE/installation will stop with a prompt before it starts doing lots of setup stuff.  I'm not sure for this case if that it's early enough.  If not, you can specify `suspend=y` to make the JVM stop right on startup. But probably you won't need that and be careful with this because it will appear as if nothing happen and that Eclipse didn't start, and it won't start until you attach a debug agent...

In the Oomph IDE we have this launcher:

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/d9d9dea3-35ad-4afb-a9e6-91fcf2652967)

So then one can attach a debug to the installation and debug what's going on via normal breaks.  Even hot replace often works...

title: NA
body:
Thanks again for your help @merks!

I've set this up and I'm now debugging this. I can tell you:

1. `fileArtifactRepository` is `null` on L124
2. `artifactRepositoryManager.contains(uri)` returns `false`
3. `createRepository()` throws an exception containing a `detailMessage` of `Repository already exists at file:/Users/marklawrence/.p2/pool/.`

Interestingly, when that exception is caught. if I put a watch on `artifactRepositoryManager.contains(uri)`, it then returns `true`.

I'll slap some more breakpoints in, try to find when things get populated.

title: NA
body:
Ahh, I think I know why this is happening now after stepping through the code. 

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/09b3fd7e-b84b-4f32-ab8d-432f77ab3144)

In our oomph profile I'm doing some hacking around to the files that contain the update sites, so that they're disabled when people run 'check for updates'. (I only really want people using oomph to get updates via oomph)
As part of that, there were a few lines in those files specific to the individual users pool directory. In our oomph, through one way or another, I've had those lines removed on a fresh install.

The line `artifactRepositoryManager.contains(uri)` is going to check the pool directory is a known repository (and more than likely uses these files I've hacked to consult its one it knows about), it doesn't find it because of what I've done in our Oomph, therefore tries to create it.
It likely adds it back into the repository/update sites list before trying to create the location, at which point it goes bang.

I'll stop what I'm doing with the update site/repository list files, and see if that resolves it, then I'll close the ticket.

title: NA
body:
Yes, working fine now I've disabled those tasks! I'll have to find another way of disabling update sites, or I might just mirror some internally so they only update when I update them.

Thank you again for your help @merks as always!

title: NA
body: It’s truly a pleasure to help people who show so much initiative!

title: Cannot run latest installer on RHEL 8.10
body:
I'm trying out latest Installer from the nightly to verify that a totally different bug I'm planning to report doesn't exist in the latest installer and found that latest no-longer works on RHEL 8.10.
I get this:

```
[cloudusr@oomph-linux eclipse-installer]$ ./eclipse-inst 
./eclipse-inst: /lib64/libc.so.6: version `GLIBC_2.33' not found (required by ./eclipse-inst)
./eclipse-inst: /lib64/libc.so.6: version `GLIBC_2.34' not found (required by ./eclipse-inst)
```

Is there any way to get support for this back? Upgrading glibc to the versions being mentioned appears to be a no hoper.

My company only allow RHEL 8.10 currently, so my team are stuck with that OS for the time being.

I can use an earlier version of the Installer as I have been, but I've found a bug, which would be nice to have resolved....I'll report in a seperate issue.

title: NA
body:
That sounds like the same problem as described here:

https://github.com/orgs/eclipse-oomph/discussions/127

An incompatible change in SWT is not a problem that I can easily fix for you without getting stuck in the past myself... 

Of course n principle it's possible to build against earlier version of SWT.  But my resource is limited...

title: NA
body:
Ah, sorry @merks I didn't spot that (never thought about looking through the discussions tab, will do from now on).

Yes, this is a duplicate of that. 

This does makes me nervous though, because it kind of means we're reaching the ceiling of our Eclipse Installer use, and we'd likely have to stick at the version of Eclipse we're on now, and on oomph 1.35.0 for the foreseeable. As well as, Eclipse Installer from the main Eclipse site won't work for back level Linux versions anymore.

Forking and doing our own build pipeline makes sense, as I can bake the customisations into that, rather than doing things half manually/half scripted later. I'm guessing it could be as simple as running [this in Jenkins](https://github.com/eclipse-oomph/oomph/blob/master/releng/org.eclipse.oomph.parent/Jenkinsfile) with some modifications, and the repackage.sh?

In terms of the changes, I only really spotted [this](https://github.com/eclipse-oomph/oomph/commit/9d336879e62869403c8e9394bbb7bb6ef09dd3a2) as potentially causing the issue, so I could reverse the change?

In the meantime, I'll stick to using 1.35.0, and live with any issues in there.

title: NA
body: Yes, it should not be difficult to reproduce the build...

title: NA
body: I didn't realize that the oomph installer was already using pre-release eclipse executables. I am working on this issue in https://github.com/eclipse-equinox/equinox/issues/830 as I don't think we should release eclipse that has this problem.

title: NA
body: I too would prefer that a wider range of consumers can continue to functional well without hassles...

title: NA
body:
@Mark-J-Lawrence 

I'm going to close this as fixed because as I understand it, the latest equinox launcher and the latest SWT should just work so the latest nightly build installer should be working now.  If that's not the case, please let us know...

title: `License Confirmation Disabled` possibly broken?
body:
I have an Oomph setup, where all P2 tasks have `License Confirmation Disabled` set to `true`.

This is an attempt at installing that profile on an Installer at version `1.35.0 Build 900`, and you can see the setting is honoured and is `true`:

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/4e247fa1-5a4f-4190-8d6b-ff462d1ebc63)


This is now an attempt at installing exactly the same profile at exactly the same source, on a RHEL 8.10 machine using an Installer at `1.35.0 Build 956`. The License Confirmation Disabled settings are not honoured and its set to `false`. I've seen this happen for Windows also.

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/8a594344-ce00-4e49-a1a7-3c0a670c78ab)

I've found this bug, as I obviously started getting a lot of pop-up dialogs during installs asking for license acceptance.

Between these builds, I've noticed `org.eclipse.oomph.p2.core` has changed, not sure if the changes in there might give any clues?

title: NA
body: I forgot we even have such an option on the p2 task.  I can try to find time to test if that is working or not for me...

title: NA
body: I tested (with a locally built installer) both disabled and not disabled and only got a license prompt when not disabled.  I also can't think of anything that would have caused a change in behavior...

title: NA
body: No problem, thanks for confirming @merks. I'll have a further dig my end and update the ticket.

title: NA
body:
I'm going to close this down. As part of gutting everything out of our config to try and find if there's anything causing the `QueryUtil` problem, I've found that `License Confirmation Disabled` is now reporting the expected value. 

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/725fb40e-cbbb-4cdd-8b65-78fa5ef3ca2a)

There clearly must be something hidden in our config somewhere I didn't spot causing it, I'll incrementally re-add all P2 tasks to find out which one is causing it.

        <property name='download.checksum.sha-512' value='b0a0dedb16ea1bbf563e7069ada0967a7b36e0956674526af69fdb2c60455c4dbec93783e5b921d41cb0b5f1f809b86c97fc19272e65a0427a8801283be89d62'/>
```

I tried this just now:

- https://www.eclipse.org/downloads/download.php?file=/oomph/epp/2024-12/R/eclipse-inst-jre-win64.exe
- https://ftp.halifax.rwth-aachen.de/eclipse/oomph/epp/2024-12/R/eclipse-inst-jre-win64.exe

That worked fine without a prompt, and updated to the new version:

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/2aa8eaa5-25ea-48c6-a921-608dfcd2a015)

I can't test on the mac. 

Could you please try to run it like this:
```
eclipse-inst -vmargs -Duser.home=<test-user-home>
```
I.e., specify a writable folder location as the `user.home` that you can subsequently delete after testing.  I'm just trying to eliminate the possibility that something in your real user home is having an impact, e.g., if p2 knows of any file-based artifact repositories it will tend to prefer to get the artifact from that repository instead of from the internet.  (Somehow I ended up getting an unsigned version of m2e into by shared bundle pool and now I always get complaints about that.  😢)

title: Oomph contains unsigned content
body:
I did a check for updates on Oomph 1.35.0 Build 956 today and I got prompted that com.sun.jna is not signed:

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/f5ac44ee-e9ff-4669-9031-d40bfdeaeda2)

It looks like the artifact is coming from eclipse platform. 

This seems to be an Oomph specific issue as updating Eclipse Platform (eclipse-platform-4.34-linux-gtk-x86_64.tar.gz) to 4.35 (https://download.eclipse.org/eclipse/updates/4.35-I-builds/) shows the expected do you trust PGP signing on the apparently same artifact

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/e486bed3-e720-4fef-8a65-c63fc84d19d7)

I verified manually that the contents of the bundle did match the expected.

title: NA
body: Nope - seems the bundle was in my bundle pool. Not sure what I did to get it there but if I try on a clean machine I don't get the error. So unless and until I can figure out what I did to get the unsigned com.sun.jna into my bundle pool, this can be ignored.

title: Consider to provide an in-application view for notification/sponsorship
body:
For quite some time, Oomph contributes the following menu item:

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/16cfbac7-e3dc-4cd2-b11c-b2bb51c48318)

It opens a URL as specified in the Oomph catalog index so we can dynamically control and URL and the content:

https://github.com/eclipse-oomph/oomph/blob/7fe701250799b28b3568af317c9086db60242419/setups/org.eclipse.setup#L7-L13

It opens in a browser or in an editor depending on this user preference which defaults to external:

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/1ef68631-def9-4b98-9234-9148930c4c55)

There have been discussions about providing a similar type of notification via an in-application view.  

I've prototyped something rough.  Here we see the regular sponsorship link opened in an editor in the light-theme IDE along with the new view at the bottom showing how the content can be dynamically adjusted to suit the theme:

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/ccae2e78-bd3d-4f34-9abd-1baded0060f3)

E.g., here is how it looks in dark theme:

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/1b8d0bf0-df84-4445-8470-2c3dff2b76ec)

Note how the foreground and background colors match the theme.  This is accomplished by passing query parameters that can be used by the javascript of the page to adjust the appearance of the content which we can see here in an actual external browser.

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/cba7a645-247b-4669-b2c8-32ccb65fdddf)

You can contrast this with the editor showing the standard sponsorship page which is really not well-designed to be shown within a themed IDE application.

It's not 100% clear what additional value this will bring nor how best to exploit this perhaps both for potential notification, e.g., of some security problem, and for prompting interest in sponsorship.  How often should we show it?  Every startup?  Once a week on startup?  How will this be better than the current/old approach?

title: NA
body:
Hi @merks , thank you for proposing this! 

This was probably already discussed but I'll nevertheless ask the obvious question: wouldn't it suffice to let the "official" sponsor page adapt to the current theme?

The internal browser works with that too (at least for Windows)

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/0dfe0cd5-39db-47e4-a179-a78be04869ed)

title: NA
body:
First the basic background.  Sponsoring is down by 50% over the last year and a bit.  This has an impact on the IDE WG budget.  What can we do the improve this?  We are told that the webdev folks are working on design improvements.  Of course there other questions too such as why is it down? Also it would be nice to gather statistics so that when we try something different we can see what difference it makes...

In any case,  Wayne did a quick prototype of a view some time back and there was some discussion about that here:

https://github.com/waynebeaton/org.eclipse.sponsor/issues/1

As stated in that issue:

> The requirement as I understand it, is to drive more people to sponsorship. I am fully aware of the menu item in the IDE and button in the installer; they've been there for a while, so the idea is to try and do something else.

That work was presented to the IDE WG and discussed with the Planning Council.  So I'm trying to get something done to keep the issue moving forward because this has been stalled for a very long time.  I'm not personally confident that showing information in a view will make a significant difference, but it is "something else".  That being said, I do not like to waste my efforts on pointless activities...

As I see it, there are multiple angles to this:

1. How/where is the information presented?
2. How often is the information presented?
3. What information is presented?

The following is the status quo:

1. The information is presented via a URL in the default browser of the IDE, which is by default is an external browser. 
2. The URL is updated 4 times a year after the release and therefore is presented to user 4 times a year.
3. Previously https://www.eclipse.org/setups/installer/notification/ was presented but now https://www.eclipse.org/sponsor/ide/ is  presented.

Some technical considerations.  

1. The support for opening a URL allows the code to force the URL to open in an external browser but one cannot force it to open in an editor or a view if the preference is set to use an external browser.
2. We can easily update the URL once a week if we wish to present the information more often or we can easily build a timeout to present it after some elapsed time since the last time it was presented.
3. In browser the page will look fine as it is intended/designed to be displayed in a browser.  In the IDE, the view area is quite small and the content is not generally designed for that restricted size.  The editor area is bigger, but the content is still quite big and is not generally adjusting to the theme of the IDE, though of course in principle it could do that. The editor or view could be maximized.

---

Finally to your question:

> wouldn't it suffice to let the "official" sponsor page adapt to the current theme?

Take a small step back and ask yourself whether sponsorship is down because one or more of the following reasons?

- The page doesn't adjust to the theme.
- The page is shown in a browser instead of in the IDE as an editor or view.
- The page isn't shown often enough.
- The page's content does not make sponsorship compelling.

We don't have answers to any of those and basically are stalled on "try to do something else".

You'll note that there is little in the way of comments here which one can interpret in different ways:

- I don't care.
- I don't have an opinion.
- I'm not interested.
- What you plan is so awesomely perfectly I'm speechless.

title: NA
body:
Thank you @merks for the detailed explanation. I see that I've missed several nuances with my very naive proposal (thank God I'm not designing UI/UX 😅 ).

You're right: even if the webpage adapts its color to the current theme, the internal browser is smaller and the content in the page is designed/aligned to bigger windows so the result in the IDE would be subpar. One small detail though: the initial situation changed regarding the `IE` browser --> we now have `Edge` by default. But it's just a drop in a bucket, not really a difference.

I'll keep the general discussion in https://github.com/waynebeaton/org.eclipse.sponsor/issues/1 to avoid digressing here in your PR. Thank you for the pointer!

title: NA
body:
Yes, the IE thing was also a problem because it wasn't actually possible to complete the donation steps within the embedded crappy old IE browser.   I'm not 100% sure it's possible with Edge but it seems to I could get close to the final steps of donation when testing it earlier in the week.  I'm very happy with Edge because it supports modern javascript so much better!

I don't think discussing other alternatives here is a digression of the general purpose and theme of the changes this issue is looking to make.   😁

title: Provide a shortcut
body:
Once a developer starts using OOMPH extensively, there may be many many experimental OOMPHed installations and the locations of defaults may be forgotten. The built installation can be useful, but using it again later may be hard. 

Suggest that OOPMH optionally drops a short cut on the desktop that invokes the built eclipse.exe with at least the chosen Java and generated workspace.
